comments.commentBody: Amini, visiting from Germany. Would Amini in a thousand years go back to Afghanistan to rebuild "his country."  Let us get realistic.  No one wants to live there if they can get out.  We should be spending the billions we spend on shipping and resettling the Afghans to first world countries where they want to live.  Does anyone doubt that when the government collapses the Afghan kleptocrats and their families will be living in London, Munich, Los Angeles and San Francisco?  What a crime that our children are being slaughtered in this fiasco and our economy is being destroyed as well.

Alissa Rubin, Rod Nordland, and all the support staff at the Kabul bureau have my admiration, covering a story like this so well while handling the day in, day out stress of being in that place for months on end. The New York Times is lucky to have them there, especially Alissa, who I think brings a candour and rigour to that story that's often lacking.

I don't think people should overreact to this event. It's horrific, but so is everything that happens in that place. The US has to leave - the only question is how they go about it. If they choose to depart in such a way that it rips the place to shreds and leaves the region in tatters - well, that just wouldn't be smart, especially if one of the consequences would be a win for Iran. Time for America to swallow its pride, talk to the neighbours there, and work cooperatively and sensibly, rather than unilaterally and stupidly.

You may argue that the Afghan defense forces are not ready for the transition, but to be blunt, they never will be, given the strong Northern and Tajik component. There's inadquate Pashtun representation right across the field in Afghanistan, and that's the root cause of the problem. If that hasn't been addressed in 10 years, it never will be. Get out. But do it quietly, and sensibly, and in such a way that you don't cause too many more difficulties than you have already for the neighbours.

Is this attack in Kabul a dress rehearsal for something even more sinister and horrific that the mad Mullas and the Taliban( with a little bit of help from our Pakistani friends) are planning? Worthwhile for the CIA and other Intel people to probe.

To #150 - Yes, it is true that the mass media have spread the stories presented to them by those with an interest in blaming the victim. There is a movie out which illustrates this really well. It's called Hot Coffee and tells the story individuals harmed by corporations or by health care practitioners, including that of the woman who was seriously burned by McDonald's coffee while sitting in her car. This woman and her lawsuit against McDonald's became a hot topic of conversation in political and entertainment circles. The untruths - she was driving and stirring coffee, as well as the extent of her injuries, are revealed, and people who believed the lies are shocked by the truth. If they had only known the truth, they say, they would have thought differently about the incident. In the meantime, those with a reason to push lawsuit reform, used this case as its main exhibit and now it is extremely difficult for individuals to sue companies for damages in civil courts. Those who benefit the most from these distortions are the corporations, be they McDonald's or Bank of America, as the voice of ordinary citizens are silenced in the halls of justice and the halls of Congress.

So what happens is we get to vent online, but if enough people actually do something concrete about this, we might be able to get the message out there. Check out comment #116 for some other options.

Some posters want to put the blame on those who were given mortgages and ended up not being able to afford the payments.

Fist, one party was supposedly financially knowledgeable and had the means to determine the creditworthiness and ability to pay of the other party. One party supposedly had the business acumen to make a sound decision and, often, the other was financially naive. Unfortunately, a lot of people lacking in financial smarts were sold the American Dream.

Secondly, the issue here is the banks selling the secutized loans as as sound financial investment. The real problem here is that they didn't do their due diligence and thoughtfully and thoroughly investigate the soundness of the financial instruments they were dealing with. Once again, the banks supposedly have the financial investigatory resources and business acumen to look into what they are buying and selling. But, when everyone's having fun at the party, why spoil a good thing?

I already commented, but when I re-read the article I was further dismayed by this paragraph:

"Heavyweight investors that forced Bank of America to hand over billions to cover the cost of home loans that later defaulted are now setting their sights on companies like JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo, raising the prospect of more multibillion-dollar deals."

I thought the people who borrowed money would get paid, but the ones who are getting the money are the "heavyweight investors".

I'd like the authors - Mr. Schwartz and Mr. Dash to elaborate on who the "heavyweight investors" are.

I have an uneasy feeling that these are the people who bought the mortgages at bargain-basement prices when the banks saw the recession coming and sold out ASAP.

Now the "heavyweight investors" who thought they saw a great opportunity but lost their shirts are crying "foul" and want their money back. That's what "heavyweight investors" do - they look for opportunity, and sometimes things don't work out! Shouldn't all the poor individual schleps who bought Enron stock from their brokers be allowed to get their money back as well?

How come the actual mortgagees are not going to get any money back?

Requiring individuals to pay private companies for healthcare insurance moves us further from a market solution and politicizes healthcare even further. This slippery slope will open the door for every politician to push their favorite agenda and to require people to buy something that is in the public good (and gets them elected). Sad trend for American.

I hate freeloaders, no... I despise freeloaders. Freeloaders are why my insurance paid $50 for a bag of saline- salt water. Freeloaders are why my insurance paid $10 for 2 tylenol. Freeloaders are part of the reason why my insurance rates keep going up. People who are uninsured end up getting treated and not paying, thereby increasing the rates of all those who are insured. This legislation went a long ways to making sure that the freeloaders pay their share. This "forcing" someone (like Cathy @29 says) to pay for something that they may not want is absolute hogwash. Well, I am sick of freeloaders "forcing" me to pay higher insurance rates because they won't pay it.

Oh and the argument that there won't be enough docs? Looks like Mass. is doing quite well and has enough docs. They key is focus on prevention.

Here's the other issue... the abusers. Those who don't take responsibility for their actions- those who smoke or become voluntarily obese. They think that they can live their life however they want and medicine will always fix it at a huge cost to all of us. Sure you have a right to eat garbage and destroy your lungs, but I also have a right not to pay for problems that you brought on yourself. I have no issues with charging higher premiums for the abusers.

Does your 90 year old grandma need a double hip replacement where surgery would probably kill her or make her seriously ill? Does it make sense to make her live in pain for the rest of her life recovering or does it make more sense to make the rest of her life more comfortable?

In the class of abusers I also include drug companies- companies that peddle drugs that are of questionable effect. Seriously- $90,000 for a treatment that "may" extend someone's life by 1 month? Wouldn't it make more sense to spend that $90,000 to extend the life of 100 people by 5 years by helping them get preventative care?

The system is broken. It needs to be fixed. This is a start.

Absolutely on the money, save for the means of getting your point across.  Think examples not philosophical anecdotes to solidify your argument.  I can think of no better example that: "Rational agreement, properly arrived at, is the best possible justification of a claim to truth." than The Big Book of Alcoholics Anonymous.  Not written by scholars, not written to persuade, but written with consensus and cooperation and plenty of patience over hard-won concepts.  Give it a whirl Gary.  Its concise, and heartfelt- something you philosophers need some more practice with.

The importance of understanding the underpinnings of reason have vast, practical applications. Take just one very topical issue; climate change. The overwhelming consensus opinion of the scientific community is that 1) climate change is occurring, 2) the rate of change is increasing, and 3) human activity is substantially responsible for both #1 and #2. Logic and empirical evidence dictate that the consensus opinion is true, and that failing to take global action to reverse the trend will have devastating effects on society. But if the human mind is structured to see reason as a way of winning arguments, and not as a way of understanding truth, then the rationality of the argument in favor of change will not persuade those who base their denial of climate change on irrational or non-rational mental processes. And so long as a substantial portion of the population support politicians who believe in and promote arguments in denial of the truth, we are not going to take action sufficient to remedy the problem.

However, a better understanding of why some are denying the truth of the situation may be the first step to a last, best chance to convincing them to change their opinion and work toward a solution.
Once you admit magic to the process of convincing people what is true, all bets are off for a reasonable conclusion.
Regarding using logic in a group as opposed to one person: It's often said that one shouldn't argue with a fool. But a big exception to this is when there is an audience to the argument.

Logical fallacies abound in discussions of reason and the reasoning processes. The proposition that there can only be one of two outcomes, that one either seeks the truth or that one is trying to win an argument poses the question in such a way as to guarantee the possibility of an unreliable answer. There is certainly the possibility that winning an argument by dint of possession of the truth is another way to go. And citing evolutionary components in support of acting in a rationale manner need not be an either/or proposition. Recent works on evolutionary processes have also noted the importance (as Darwin himself did) of social interactions, as well as certain acts or habits that may not seem to have any biological or evolutionary advantage (nose picking, for instance, is a fairly common if socially disreputable act that at first glance does not seem to confer much in the way reproductive success), which would seem to support the importance of some kind of social agreement (not in the sense of ideological agreement which can be notoriously bias driven) based on the truth as arrived at by means of rational methods.

Social justification takes distant second place to demonstrating the accuracy of predictions made on the basis of the "truth" statement,bolstered by repetition,and elimination of observer bias. Sort of suggests the scientific method??

You know you're in trouble when a tract on reasoning starts off with an appeal to authority: 'Philosophers rightly think of themselves as experts on reasoning.' Tell me about it. What then follows is a hash-up of the source, dimly justified at first by accepting (for purposes of *argument*?) a misconception fished from the comments section of the original article.

Hugo Mercier's response in the Times, cited and belittled in the 2nd paragraph ('tried to explain') , is a model of lucidity, well worth a read.

I like the way Gutting is able to conflate the psychological and logical horns of this dilemma into a matched pair upon a contrary animal's head, and, further, I, myself, would be quite comfortable with a similar adornment. Pragmatism does seem to solve the dilemma of adaptation v. creation.

Once cannot write, read or discuss this article without first clarifying all the many uses of the word "truth." Widespread agreement about the meaning of experiments to test a given theory suggests only that many people found no flaw in the tests. For over two hundred years there was widespread agreement that gravity was the attraction at a distance between two masses, until alas . . . . This discussion could serve as evidence that Karl Popper never lived.

Ted
